title: Flaneur's guide to Cafe's in Europe
name: Flaneur's guide to Cafe's in Europe

properties.name: Aperture Cafe
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur    On Museum street, opposite the main entrance to the British Museum

properties.name: Bio Cafe
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur  If you\'re looking for a bio - organic kind of caff, this is it. If not, you\'ll be shocked at the prices. Round the corner from the AppleMac Shop where locals also marvel but spend nothing.

properties.name: Bohemia Bagel
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur What it says on the tin. Pretty much the only place making bagels in this part of the world. Right opposite Petrin Hill at Ujezd, this tends to be an expat hangout, so it\'s certainly not cheap. But... very tasty, and often fits the bill in a way that nothing else will.

properties.name: Boulevard Deli
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur It\'s a deli, it\'s a take away and it\'s a small tucked in cafe. The food is probably the best of its kind in London, but the prices don\'t nearly reflect that. And the waitresses are gorgeous. Spoil yourself.

properties.name: Cafe Adler
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur  Right at the corner of Checkpoint Charlie, Cafe Adler retains it\'s coldwar feel despite the mass tourism outside. There\'s a definite feel to the place, an authenticity. Remarkably there seemed to be quite a few locals in, and some good local food as well as great coffee, on a cold wet day. Definitely recommended if you want to let the focus slip and drift back in time to a very different world not so long ago.

properties.name: Cafe Bedetti
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur   This might seem an odd one to add, but here\'s the thing: Falconara Mma is the railway station where the line splits for various places - Rome, Venice, Bari... And while you\'re waiting for your connection, where better to sit than in the 50s gloom and general Italian dodginess of Cafe Bedetti opposite the station? In its heyday, the local hoods and ladies of transitory years and repute would command the back, while the front was devoted to reasonable coffee and... wait for it... world gold medal winning nougat and ice-cream. Really. Year after year they won the prize for \'World\'s best Torrone\'. And I want to testify to the authenticity of that award. Truly a slice of bygone Italy, all while waiting for your train.

properties.name: Cafe Ebel
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur    This is the other Cafe Ebel, opposite the Franz Kafka Museum.

properties.name: Cafe Jericho
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur  Local to the point of austerity - I\'m still trying to work out what they do actually serve. A little reminiscent of a council community space but with some charm.

properties.name: Cafe Rybka
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur  Cafe Rybka is situated about 200 metres from Narodni Trida tube station towards the river, in Prague 2.

properties.name: Cafe Savoy
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur  Cafe Savoy is situated between Petrin hill and the river, on the Ujezd side of Legii Most. Here\'s their own page: http://www.ambi.cz/ambi_cafesavoy_kontakt_eng.php

properties.name: Cafe Shadow
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur  Again, does what it says on the tin. If you\'re looking for a shadowy world reminiscent of a sixth form common room, this is it.

properties.name: Cafe Slavia
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur    On the river by Legii Most, opposite the National Theatre, Cafe Slavia is an institution in itself. One of the Big Three.

properties.name: Cafe Velryba
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur   The \'Big Fish\' round the corner from the \'Little Fish\', velryba has great decor, great food and great prices.

properties.name: Cafe in the Garden
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur    Situated in the gardens of Bloomsbury Square. Russell Square Tube is nearest and several buses terminate here, including the 7 and 188.

properties.name: Carluccios
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur After a rumoured £100million facelift, the Brunswick Centre now even boasts a Carluccios. Expensive, but serious quality.

properties.name: Chez Flaneur
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur  Not strictly speaking a cafe (though i wonder sometimes) but if you email me I might just invite you in for a cuppa.

properties.name: Ciao Bella
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur Actually an Italian restaurant on Lamb\'s Conduit Street, near Great Ormond Street Hospital and Mecklenburg Square. But it does great coffee, too.

properties.name: Clerkenwell Music
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur  In Exmouth market, which despite rapid meeja gentrification does now have a market again. Jeremy has just put a coffee bar in his record shop, and it\'s great.

properties.name: Coffee, Cake and Kink
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur On Endell street, but with such small frontage you\'d miss it. Does what it says on the tin. Fantastic erotic art, photography and merchandise. And cake.

properties.name: Coram Cafe
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur  The most wonderful cafe that seriously hardly anyone knows about. Attached to the Coram Foundling Museum, it too seems to evoke the decorum of a bygone era.

properties.name: Costa Coffee, Waterloo Railway Station
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur  No, really. It\'s such a good place to people watch. Waterloo has great light. Get someone to guard a seat/table while you get the drinks in. All the staff have badges for their country of origin - do you know what the Georgian flag looks like?

properties.name: Crockatt & Powell
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur Crockatt & Powell are an independent bookseller in Lower Marsh, Waterloo. Ok, they\'re not actually a cafe, but there are several nearby (including the wonderful Scooterworks). These guys are included because they\'re a great Flaneur hangout. Being independent means they can stock fascinating and unusual books that you will never find in the big high street bookshops that have major publishers breathing down their necks about what to stock and where to place things. Oh, and they\'re friendly guys, too.

properties.name: Cvit Kabu
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur  The best cafe in Lviv (of the open ones, at least). It opens pretty early and seems a favourite among the well-heeled on their way to work. Coffees from all over the world, and the taste is world class. Some English spoken too. A real life saver if you can find it.

properties.name: Epoca
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur  Run by Frank, of Frank\'s further up the road, but a very different gaff. For my money Epoca make the best cappuccino in London.

properties.name: Franks
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur In the bustle towards Covent Garden at the Shaftesbury Avenue end of Neal street. More a caff than a cafe, but great sanwiches and tea, first rate fry-up, filling Italian food and the staff are brill.

properties.name: Great Court Cafe, British Museum
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur    has to be seen to be believed... to be reviewed soon!

properties.name: Kaficko
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur   Great cafe just off the main Charles Bridge drag, but it\'s quiet, well-priced and very friendly.

properties.name: Kava Kava Kava
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur Situated at Andel, at the beginning of Lidicka, on the left, as you walk towards the river.

properties.name: Kavarna Dobra Trafika II
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur Another one you\'d really have to know about, but well worth it. Looks like a Trafika from the front, but pass through the shop and there\'s a fairly extensive little cafe in the back with it\'s own garden - really nice in the summer. Great value breakfasty stuff. Art on the walls, too.

properties.name: Kavarna Vojtecha
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur  Nice little place just off the river, round the back of the film school and the church. Nice light for reading.

properties.name: Kavarna v Sedmem Nebe
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur Seventh Heaven cafe. Busy little place with quieter back rooms, and a great little upstairs. Some interesting art on the walls. Good little place if you don\'t walk right by it.

properties.name: Krakow Main Square
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur There are many bars all around the edges of the square, and they kind of merge into one another. Just look for the make of beer they serve on their umbrella, and remember - Polish and Czech beer is cheaper and tastes ten times better than imported stuff! The key here is not so much the establishment as the view...

properties.name: Lemon Leaf Cafe
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur Just off the main Charles Bridge thoroughfare. Friendly, good food, good tea, even. That\'s a rarity. So is listening to students practice at the music academy opposite while you drink it.

properties.name: Living Space
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur    This internet cafe’s environmentally friendly design features include an eco-friendly air cooling system, computers and internet powered by solar panels on the grass roof, where rainwater is harvested and re-used to flush all the toilets. How eco is that?

properties.name: London Review Bookshop
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur Is, of course, a bookshop, not a cafe. But it\'s a stunning one-of-a-kind bookshop, and a serious flaneur place to be. And there are cafes all around it, let\'s face it.

properties.name: Metropolitan Books
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur Situated in Exmouth Market, Metropolitan is an independant bookshop, so there are more interesting and unusual books more readily found here than in any of the high street chains. Phil supports local authors as well as local shoppers which is cool, too. Metropoilitan is place most likely to bump into Magnus Mills, Jake Arnott, and... er... most of The Guardian and ITN.

properties.name: NFT Cafe
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur   The National Film Theatre cafe, under Waterloo Bridge, right on the South Bank, sit and watch the passers by, and check out the book stalls beneath the bridge.

properties.name: Neal's Yard
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur Tucked away behind Neal Street and Seven Dials, New Age meets art meets world food. Really good vibe. Man.

properties.name: Night and Day Bar
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur On Southampton row amongst the hotels near the east side of Bloomsbury Square Gardens, this cafe actually is open night and day.

properties.name: Odessa Beach
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur    Sure, there are some great cafes in the town, but when the air gets thick with fumes (and it does) there\'s only one place to head - the beach. Several cafes here, and to be honest, one\'s as good as another. Prices aren\'t too bad - beer\'s cheaper than coffee, and ice-cream\'s a steal. Great views however you look at it - still a working port up the beach, and still the beach where Muscovites flock to spend their time and money.

properties.name: Petrin Tower Cafe
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur    If you do make it all the way up here without the aid of the furnicular railway, it\'s good to know there\'s a cafe at the tower. It\'s not great, but it\'s here.

properties.name: Post Punk Cafe
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur   Situated in the old Jewish Market Square of kazimierz in Krakow.

properties.name: Post Punk Cafe
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur   Situated in the old Jewish market square of Kazimierz.

properties.name: Scooterworks
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur   Scooterworks is probably the hippest cafe in London. Really. A 60s feel hangout for Waterloo and Lower Marsh locals, including writers, travellers and film makers, this cafe just happens to be the best place to get your Italian scooter serviced.

properties.name: Sklep v Kawa
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur   The finest coffee i tasted in Warsaw, and possibly the world. Single estate coffees here, hand brewed in front of you, and even better, perfect mixes of cardomum, ginger and spices for an espresso with heavenly aroma and fortification against the Polish winter.

properties.name: St Martins Cafe
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur  Look for a small set of steps leading down into the crypt below St Martins Church. A slightly odd feel to the cafe, but the crypt is huge, belying the entrance.

properties.name: The Poetry Place
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur Down residential Betterton Street, off Endell Street, you\'d never know this cafe was here. This has to be the ultimate flaneur\'s hang out.

properties.name: Treadwell's
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur Just off the strand in the heart of theatreland, Treadwells is actually a bookshop, but they\'ll make you cups of tea and sit you on their sofa. Another ultimate flaneur hangout, worthy of a big review very soon.

properties.name: Valtaro's
properties.description: Posted by Flaneur Greasy spoon in the heart of Bloomsbury, and it\'s open on Sundays. Cracking fry-up, generous with their bacon, and the prices are good.
